title: Owen Farrell celebration explained: What the England fly-half’s ‘Jack salute’ means
text:
The Lions star makes the gesture with his fingers after every score (Picture: Getty)

Owen Farrell has scored more points than any other England player bar Jonny Wilkinson and his celebration has become a common sight for fans at Twickenham and beyond.

The 28-year-old is currently desperate to right the wrongs of 2015 where he and the host nation crashed out in the group stages, the first ever home team to do it at a Rugby World Cup.

Farrell will hope to lift the Webb Ellis Cup in November in Japan but whether he does or not, there is always something bigger in his mind whenever he lands a kick for England.

The Saracens fly-half tends to wait until he is up on the big screen after scoring points, before linking his hands by the forefingers in a ‘celebration’ that reaches out to a cause close to his heart.

Jack Johnson, now 11, was diagnosed with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, a terminal muscle-wasting disease, in October 2011 – Jack’s father Andy played rugby league with Farrell’s own father, another Andy, at Wigan.

‘The whole [Farrell] family have an amazing, ethical attitude,’ Jack’s mother Alex told The Times.

‘They just want to help other people. When Andrew was coach of England, he invited Jack down to Pennyhill Park.

‘Jack was tackling Big Faz [Farrell Sr] and Big Faz was falling down as though Jack had absolutely smashed him.

‘We take a team of legends from league and union to the Dubai Sevens every year.

Owen Farrell and father Andy are friends with the Johnson family (Picture: Getty)

‘In 2015, Owen spent the whole time playing with Jack.

‘He’d pick up Jack and run him onto the pitch so Jack could give out water to the players.’

The ‘Jack salute’ involves linking the two forefingers in the shape of the initials ‘JJ’ and has been seen every time Farrell has scored points ever since 2014.

The England captain is not the only sporting celebrity to have whipped out the celebration either.

Rio Ferdinand, Bradley Wiggins, Jessica Ennis-Hill, Alan Shearer and Tim Henman have all been pictured supporting the charity, but Farrell remains the most high-profile current sportsman.

‘If the cause touches you enough, it becomes part of your thinking instinctively, especially when you can reach out to such a big audience,’ Owen says of his involvement with Joining Jack, which has been raising money for research into the disease since 2012.

‘When you understand the lack of awareness of such a condition, everyone has to jump on board and do their bit.’
